posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
This comes on the back of Mental Dekay's thread about combining these classes: Rogue/ CoT/ WM

And then I watched the 300 again, and thought maybe...

One thing that annoys me (yes, another one) with NwN rules is that spear is incompatible with shield, which is clearly out of whack with history (hoplites, anyone?), and renders the AC pretty nasty - though it could be worse, and shortsword and shield is available to give a boost if needed. I've kept all the saves at 20+, which isn't bad for a straight melee build. I haven't worked through the skills points yet, but there's plenty to cover Discipline, Tumble, UMD, cross-classed Spellcraft and a detect skill (Spot/Listen) with spares. He's also got an AB of 46, which is nice.

There are a few things in particular I'd like advice on (though please feel free to come up with your own nuggets). I wonder about what to take as one of the  pre-epic feats: Toughness, Great Fortitude, Martial Weapons Proficiency, or Heavy Armour Proficiency (though that last one would go against the concept). I'm also not sure whether that +1AB from WM 16 is better than a +2 to saves from a Rogue 13/ CoT 14/ WM 13.

Anyway, your thoughts would be appreciated on this first draft. Now second draft - changes in red.

LEONIDAS (Rogue 14/ CoT 10/ WM 16)
Human, any non-evil
L1-40 PvM

Stats
STR 17 (34)
DEX 14
CON 14
WIS 8
INT 13
CHA 8

Hit Points: 424 [464 if Toughness taken]
AC: (naked) 22, (med armour - breastplate/ chain mail) 27, with shortsword + tower shield 30, with Expertise 32/ 35 (+1 Dodge, +4 vs AoO)
Saves: Fort 26 [28 if Great Fort taken], Will 20 22, Reflex 30 (all +4 vs spells, +3 Reflex vs traps)
BAB: 27
AB: (spear) 46/ 41/ 36/ 31: (shortsword) 41/ 36/ 31/ 26: (ranged) 30/ 25/ 20/ 15
Sneak Attack: 7d6
Skills: [a little vague atm, but around 230 and around 200 for Disc, Spellcraft, Spot or Listen, Tumble and UMD] 274. Discipline 43 (55), Intimidate (cc) 4 (3), Listen 43 (42) OR Spot 43 (42), Spellcraft (cc) 19 (20), Tumble 40 (42), UMD 36 (35), 66 spare for social, stealth, trapping skills, or Lore or Heal, depending on environment/ preference.

Levelling
1 R1 - Dodge/ Expertise
2 R2 - {Evasion}
3 R3 - Mobility/ {UD1}
4 R4 - STR+1 (18)
5 R5
6 R6 - KD
7 R7
8 R8 - STR+1 (19)
9 R9 - WF: Spear Shortsword (could be swapped with Mobility at L3)
10 R10 - {Crippling Strike}
11 CoT1
12 CoT2 - STR+1 (20)/ Blind Fight OR second WF (see above) WF: Spear/ Blind Fight
13 CoT3
14 CoT4 - ICrit: Spear
15 CoT5 - IKD Iron Will
16 CoT6 - STR+1 (21)/ Spring Attack IKD
17 CoT7
18 R11 - Toughness OR Great Fort OR Heavy Armour OR Blind Fight (if taking a second WF at L12) Spring Attack
19 CoT8 - WW Attack
20 CoT9 - STR+1 (22)
21 CoT10 - Grt Str I (23)/ EWF: Spear
22 WM1 - {WoC: Spear}
23 WM2
24 WM3 - STR+1 (24)/ Grt Str II (25)
25 WM4
26 WM5
27 WM6 - Grt Str III (26)
28 R12 - STR+1 (27)
29 WM7
30 WM8 - Grt Str IV (28)
31 WM9
32 R13 - STR+1 (29)/ {Imp Evasion OR Slippery Mind} {Slippery Mind}
33 WM10 - Grt Str V (30)
34 WM11
35 WM12
36 WM13 - STR+1 (31)/ Grt Str VI (32)/ Armour Skin
37 R14
38 WM14
39 WM15 - Grt Str VII (33)
40 WM16 - STR+1 (34)/ Epic Prowess

Cheers

Made a few more amendments (11/12/19) following MD's input.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content: I would suggest switching from Rog11/CoT9 pre-epic to Rog12/CoT8 since it gives +1 Fortitude and +1 Reflex. The only downside is that you'll have fewer epic rogue levels for skill dumps.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks, Yunim. The saves would always be welcome (I really hate failing Will saves as a meleer - it stops you doing the one thing you're supposed to do - but it's an occupational hazard much of the time, which is why I tend towards CoT rather then Fighter a fair bit. And I appreciate there's no Will bump in your suggestion).

There is one more downside (which probably makes more difference in modules than on PWs), though, and that's the delay of EWF by at least one level. It's one for me to mull on.

I'd also thought about delaying the final 3 levels of CoT into epic levels and bringing the first 2 WM levels in pre-epic (taking WW Attack at level 18 and negating my quandary over which feat to take then and maybe grabbing something else as my "floating" CoT bonus feat in epic levels).

Hmm...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi Stag

Delighted to read through your build as always and learn from what you are doing!

Lots of nice things in your build, including taking seven great strength feats plus 7d6 sneak attack (which can be triggered by flanking with summons from UMD, or improved knockdown) with a very good 46 base AB with potentially two weapon foci and 34 strength

Firstly I do not think you can take Weapon Focus: Spear with Weapon Proficiency (Rogue), hence I would encourage you to go the dual foci route for your build in terms of achieving your CoT requirements then take the WF: Spear once you get CoT

I personally like the idea of dual foci to wield a xiphos (greek shortsword) and large shield (gotta be a round shield if you are Spartan, sorry tower shields) and dropping heavy armor proficiency (I don't recall many spartans clad in heavy plate, they are meant to intimidate with their biceps), and I like the idea of blind fight in the build over toughness. I don't think you would lose a lot of AC by equipping a chain shirt then boosting dex a little with items / UMD / cats grace potions.

I can see Yunim's suggestion would be best for a max power level 40 build, but the extra skill dumps are better in a build which plays along its lifetime with termination near 40 (I'm thinking Aielund), losing one skill dump epic might mean 5 levels where your rogue skills are not effective enough. All depends on the environment

In terms of skill points I would ensure there is 4 ranks in intimidate during your rogue levels (Weapon Master Prerequisite), Tumble 40. 

Beyond that you have a lot of choices. Here are some suggestions. I'm sure you know a lot about this but I put it up there, just in case

UMD: I would take this simply because it is so good, if you dont want to cast spells then use it so you can use any equipment you need to, like a brutal survivor a Spartan is, you can use those Monk Boots if needed
Detection: Agree with either Listen or Spot, I would choose Listen if you go stealth based
Stealth: Potentially a good choice with a two handed and medium armor, with your dex score but will use up a lot of your skill points
Discipline: A good choice in some modules, particularly if there are opponents who use disarm / called shot. Essential if knockdown immunity is not available or difficult to obtain.
Traps: Set trap 15 modified is handy to set all deadly traps except gas traps, disable trap is also handy to get some bonus exp or retrieve traps to use against your enemies
Social skills: Persuade is handy in a few modules, Appraise is also handy in environments which are cash strapped
Spellcraft: is ok for + saves against spells, particularly if you dont want to use buffs from UMD or dont have access to them

Hope that helps!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi Stag, noted you posted whilst I was typing my suggestions, I think the saves would be better with three classes pre-epic (ie Rogue / WM / CoT) but am not 100% sure, my understanding is the first 1-2 levels one gets large benefits for the primary saves of the class

By the way the shortsword early -> large spear later can be incorporated into a nice way from an RP point of view, its kind of like the young spartan, scrounging around for any advantage with a borrowed or stolen shortsword, surviving at all costs, finally earning his stripes, becoming a champion of Sparta and getting that huge powerful spear to smite the enemy, with such a high base Str that is very strong

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, balls, you're right about spear, Orion - it's a simple weapon not a Rogue weapon. And that's right about the saves - WM2 would give a nice +3 to Reflex, but I'd lose 1 in both Fort and Will, which would then kind of reinforce my Rogue 13/ CoT 14/ WM 13 thought.

Alright, time for a bit of a rethink. Nurse!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I only have one thing to nitpick!

Just sayin'!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
A Rogue/CoT/WM build screams for the Rapier. But that's not Sparta!!!
The CEP Goad may look like a one handed spear, but you cannot take any feats in it. Another solution would be if you were able to trick the game into treating your character as one size bigger so you could wield the spear in one hand. (I don't know if it's even possible)
-
I found two almost identical builds with these classes in my folders. They were both Rogue 13/ CoT 8/ WM 19 with Rogue 10/ CoT 6/ WM4 pre epic, and ended up with AB +47 and a will save bonus of 19. But they were Rapier builds with Armor proficiency heavy, so no Spatra there. (So I dont even know if this is helpful) The stats were STR: 17 (34), DEX: 13, CON: 14, WIS: 8, INT: 14, CHA: 8.
I took Crippling strike like you did, but chose Defensive roll for the second rogue feat. Slippery mind may be better and suits your attempt to avoid mind spells.
I list the skills for comparison. With INT 14 I could pick one more skill and had room for a little extra:
Build 1: Appraise 13(15), Craft Trap 19(21), Disable Trap 12(16), Discipline 43(55), Intimidate 4(3), Listen 43(42), Lore 8(10), Open Lock 28(29), Persuade 13(12), Search 40(42), Set Trap 12(15), Tumble 40(41), UMD 36(35)
Build 2: Appraise 13(15), Craft Trap 19(21), Disable Trap 12(16), Discipline 43(55), Intimidate 4(3), Listen 43(42), Open Lock 13(14), Persuade 13(12), Search 40(42), Set Trap 12(15), Tumble 40(41), UMD 36(35), remaining skillpoints 23.
I could have x-classed Spellcraft here for better saves vs spells.
-
Levelling up such a build may be a challenge early on when you have a strength based rogue with only light armor and no shield. But I guess you can write that off as "Spartan hardship".
-
Orion brought up Aielund.
That sparked some thoughts and questions about how such a character would have acted throughout that campaign. How would a Spartan lost in Aielund have interacted with the different NPCs? What path would it take and who would he choose to party up with?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Hmmm...the trick with the "one size bigger" brings back memories...

I had a Troll Character that dualwielded Greatswords! (using the "one size bigger" trick).

I rather suspect, as Mick says, that it would be possible to wield the Spear this way one-handedly, and use a Shield!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
There is a CEP 'Shortspear' weapon which can be wielded in one hand, and one can equip a shield in the other.
I have seen a few of these floating around in WoG.

The main problem with using this is that one cannot weapon focus / epic weapon focus it, which is why I haven't suggested it but Mick has brought up the Goad CEP weapon so I thought I would mention it.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks All - invaluable input! I'll edit the OP shortly to accommodate what I can (I'll do it in red so it shouldn't be too confusing).

I will be going for the two weapon foci (shortsword - as Mick says, rapier is probably the "better" choice, but RP must play its part, and even then a shortsword should really be both piercing and slashing, much as a greatsword should be both slashing and bludgeoning, but I digress - then spear). With the same class split, I'll still have a reasonable 41 AB with shortsword.

The skills breakdown from Mick is very helpful. First, it makes it easier for me to do the sums, which is always nice. Second, again given the RP nature of the build, I'm not really looking for trapping skills (maybe a few points in Disable), so an INT of 13 seems right in this instance, giving me an albeit teeny bump to DEX.

As to the "one size bigger" thought, I like it, but suspect it will remain just that, a nice thought (and as a side-effect it would also seriously boost IKD).

Mick is right that early levels will be challenging, particularly if soloing, but that should help hone my playing skills, looking on the sunny side!

And the Aielund question is an interesting one, and I'll try running the build around there to see how it fares (though I don't recall seeing many quality spears there, but then I haven't been looking for them before. It's also a non-Dev Crit environment, so might suit this build). I don't see him getting on terribly well with Robert Black or Terinus, but he'd probably really like Valennia and maybe Maggie (for her passion), and have a love-hate relationship with Dante. The other henchies I'm thinking he'd have no really strong feelings about either way (so maybe no romance with Criosa).

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Edit now done and ready for dissection...

posts.author: MentalDekay
posts.content:
As an MSU Spartan, I endorse this build. I'm glad to be an inspiration. :) 

As warriors, I believe they trained in both spears and shortswords (a wikipedia tangent show it was called a xiphos). So the dual weapon focus is nice touch. Alas, if only there was a way around the shield problem. :'(
Spoiler"Spartans! What is you profession?"
As a builder, I'm finding myself super fond of CoT builds. Failing saves can ruin my play time. For pure offense though, it seems like R/F/CoT comes out on top.

I put this into the CBC spreadsheet (being a math/stat geek, I'm always curious how builds compare in CR and ECL ratings. Even if it's an imperfect measurement like bWAR or fWAR). It seems like you were off a couple points as Intimidate isn't cross-classed. Plus, I think you missed a feat at level 15.
Spoiler Rogue(14), Champion of Torm(10), Weapon Master(16), Human STR: 17 (34) CON: 14 INT: 13 01: Rogue(1): Dodge, Expertise 03: Rogue(3): Mobility, {Uncanny Dodge I} 05: Rogue(5) 07: Rogue(7) 09: Rogue(9): Weapon Focus: Shortsword 11: Champion of Torm(1) 13: Champion of Torm(3): {Smite Evil} 15: Champion of Torm(5): Iron Will 17: Champion of Torm(7) 19: Champion of Torm(8): Whirlwind Attack 21: Champion of Torm(10): Great Strength I, Epic Weapon Focus: Spear, (STR=23) 23: Weapon Master(2) 25: Weapon Master(4) 27: Weapon Master(6): Great Strength III, (STR=26) 29: Weapon Master(7) 31: Weapon Master(9) 33: Weapon Master(10): Great Strength V, (STR=30) 35: Weapon Master(12) 37: Rogue(14) 39: Weapon Master(15): Great Strength VII, (STR=33) Skillpoints: 274 Saving Throw bonuses: Spells: +4, Traps: +3 AB (max, naked): 46 (melee), 30 (ranged) Spell Casting:  01: Intimidate(4), Listen(4), Spellcraft(2), Tumble(4), UMD(4), Save(20),  03: Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Tumble(1), UMD(1), Save(32),  05: Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Tumble(1), UMD(1), Save(44),  07: Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Tumble(1), UMD(1), Save(56),  09: Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Tumble(1), UMD(1), Save(68),  11: Discipline(14), Spellcraft(1), Save(63),  13: Discipline(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(67),  15: Discipline(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(71),  17: Discipline(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(75),  19: Discipline(2), Spellcraft(1), Save(61),  21: Discipline(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(65),  23: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(64),  25: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(66),  27: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(68),  29: Discipline(2), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(56),  31: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(58),  33: Discipline(2), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(58),  35: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(60),  37: Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Tumble(5), UMD(1), Save(63),  39: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(66), 
Also, I'd think any of the rogue skills (traps, Hide, MS, OL) would completely fit with their warrior upbringings/training.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Just by way of an update...

This is damned hard work up to level 14 or so, and the AC remains a challenge throughout - you will take punishment. On this basis, I don't propose to shift it to the finalized builds forum. It does, however, help hone your playing skills, which is never a bad thing.

A shame, but an enjoyable play!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I found pure rogue challenging to play when I started. In this build the player has to play pure rogue for 10 or so levels.

Rogue has as you recall, d6 hit die, 3/4 BAB, restricted to light armor and no shield proficiency. 
Fighter has d10 hit die, full BAB, heavy armor, shield and martial weapon proficiency, concentration/discipline as a class skill

Man - o - Mano, 1v1 melee fair duel combat wise -> Fighter will always have a significant advantage over Rogue. 

This is assuming no usage of stealth, traps, UMD, cheesy ranged kiting tricks with tumble, or using summons/companions to flank your opponent (or sneak attacks with a shortbow).

I obtained a lot of advice from other players to improve my rogue gameplay. 

In summary I believe rogue has three advantages over fighters:
- sneak attack
- skills (8 skill points / level vs 2 skill points / level), most of them class skills, exception of discipline/concentration
- evasion / uncanny dodge etc..

Combat relevant skills are broken down into
-> stealth / detection
-> traps
-> UMD
-> tumble

I'm still learning rogue stuff all the time from other players. Gkorjax for example, was kind enough to party with me the other day, and taught me the power of the humble 'wand of sleep'. Enemies with limited hit die who are asleep can be assassinated very easily with coup de grace.

AC wise thankfully this build has Dex 14. I've played pure rogue builds with Dex 8 and they are awful to level. 

Overall I think you are being somewhat harsh on judging your build which a lot of people have contributed towards to make it optimal and I would encourage you to reconsider, it might just be in the hands of a skilled rogue player those early levels one might do fine...

For example in the original campaign, if you have a suitable melee companion tank for you, you will be doing a lot of sneak damage. Level 10 rogue is 5d6 sneak damage, that is more than two greatswords in a single hit. 

If they target you, use tumble and get away from them, kite them until they retarget your companion, then sneak again. Maybe you could even use a shortbow in that situation to make it easier, although if they do get into melee range you will suffer -4 to AB, but I think if you are within 15 feet the sneak attack will activate without the AB penalty (?anyone can confirm)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
It's kind of you to say so, Orion, but I'm aware I'm still first and foremost a player, a critic second (just because I've digested so many builds, I guess), and a builder third. And when I do build, they tend to be more conceptual in nature, rather than optimized, and as a module rather than PW player, I appreciate playability throughout more than max level 40 power. And that's fine: we all have our stengths and weaknesses, after all.

I have learned to play in many contrasting styles depending on build and environment - more often than not because this lot provide so many builds I want to play. Normally, somewhere around level 10 I know if it's "my kind of thing" or not, but sometimes I keep ploughing on anyway because I can be a stubborn bugger (I know, scarcely believable!), and those will end up as being the most valuable ones, as I learn new ways of playing. Casters still bring me out in hives, but hey, we can't have everything.

I still don't think this particular beastie warrants a place in the pantheon, though. And I do try to respect the level 40 forum as the best of the best.

Cheers

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Orion2019 wrote: ↑
Jan 08, 2020
  I've played pure rogue builds with Dex 8 and they are awful to level.
That makes me wonder why you would do such a thing
I like my rogues much better when they start out with Dex 18 or thereabout without neglecting Intelligence.

With Sneak attack you can kill a giant with a finessed toothpick or a sling
Sneak immunes you kill with traps or contraptions you can use with your UMD skill
The same goes for True seers
Versatility and creativity is key. What you call tactics, less open-minded players call cheesy.

But c'mon - Fighters do what fighters do. Playing a pure rogue is a different game altogether.
Fighter rogues like the Spartan one posted here pick a little from both worlds - versatility once more. But I still don't like playing in the undies with a dexterity of 14.

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:
I know some know this already but it bears repeating...   Traps are great.. but take time to  put into place...  remember this...

tanglefoot bag is a reflex save versus held for 2 rounds
choking powder is a fort save against dazed for 2 rounds...
caltrops - 1 damage every rounds.. 25 max.  

so if you don't use them to make traps...  a caltrop bag following by whichever is their weaker save then reposition and sneak...

or skip the caltrops and get 2 rounds of sneaks in....

and sleep wands..  and wands of entangle...  and wands of stinking cloud.... and you have UMD  :)     use it...    

the only reason you play fair is cause your Ma or Da gave you a hangup about being a paladin....

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: ↑
Jan 09, 2020
Orion2019 wrote: ↑
Jan 08, 2020
  I've played pure rogue builds with Dex 8 and they are awful to level.
That makes me wonder why you would do such a thing
I like my rogues much better when they start out with Dex 18 or thereabout without neglecting Intelligence.
Mick if you remember, I wrote a Blackguard Executioner build some months back. It had a starting strength of 16-17 and dex of 8, con 16, in 14 something like that. Originally I designed it with 8 levels of rogue before the first level of blackguard, however I learned 8 levels of pure rogue, strength based, dex 8 is just too painful in light armor and no shield proficiency, the only way to win fights was with UMD. This was my first proper rogue build, and just part of the learning process called experience. It was funny, I had a chat to BlackCobra whilst playing WoG the other day, and he had a similar experience too, he had to expend extreme effort just to buff up that AC. 

And thus through similar experiences we share common ground :)

Mick and conlaoch's comments do echo my own except with a lot more experience behind them. I only learned about the power of caltrops recently, particularly against opponents such as animals (rust monsters for example) who can't open doors! There are multiple parts of the roguish toolkit and to get the most of the class they should be utilised, otherwise any fighter/paladin build is going to be superior. 

Regarding the dex 14 score, I believe that score is good for a human strength rogue that will eventually multiclass to a combat class, any higher and you are likely compromising your potential with strength, constitution or intelligence. Its nice too. Equip scale mail/chain shirt, drink a cats grace potion and/or equip a +2-4 dex item, and your AC is almost the same as wearing full plate, with a lot less encumberance and you can use tumble effectively early levels.

Strength rogues multiclassed with combat classes (which is Stag's build) can be absolute monsters. 

You can equip that medium/heavy armor, tower shield even, pack a punch with a huge amount of strength damage, weapon buffs from UMD (ie flame weapon/keen weapon), defensive buffs from UMD (ie improved invisibility), deal 10d6-15d6 sneak attack (which you can trigger with invisibility/flanking from companions or summons from UMD/improved knockdown or even attacking around a corner!), carry mountains of loot, devastating critical, plus you can detect and disable all the traps, open all the locks, set deadly traps (just unequip that tower), detect every stealther approaching you with listen/spot, plus you get evasion/uncanny dodge/crippling strike/improved evasion. Tank for your party etc etc. It feels like you can do everything.

Stealth is a little weaker (which rogue has bonus epic skill foci in hide and move silently if you want to use this seriously as a strength rogue) and epic dodge is generally out of the equation (I believe there are some dev crit/epic dodge builds in the ECB archives but they are rare) but these are only a few parts of the overall rogue toolkit one is missing and what is gained covers so many weaknesses of the rogue class.

Not only that its super fun to rogue up in a party with that keen weapon'ed greatsword equipped and start dishing out huge numbers from big sneak attacks & critical hits & strength damage :) Greatsword rogue! :)

Overall I think Stag build should be fine, and whilst I will always try to temper any comment with kindness, honesty and objectivity are also important to me as well. I would just treat it as part of the RP experience of the build. Suffering as a lowly spartan midget of society, and you gotta earn your space as a warrior through cunning, versatility and brutality. Perhaps princes were not excluded from the process either?

It's not easy being Spartan! :)

https://www.history.com/news/8-reasons- ... ng-spartan

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: ↑
Oct 13, 2020
Return with your shield, or on your shield!
Funny.  The build can't use a Shield, Stag!

At least, not until it gets CoT levels (and that is a looooong time coming!)

At least I have not dirtnapped yet.

This build cannot use a spear, either
 This feat allows the character to use the club, dagger, dart, handaxe, light crossbow, heavy crossbow, quarterstaff, mace, shortsword, rapier, shortbow, morningstar, and sling.

This proficiency includes all simple weapons except the sickle and SPEAR plus some martial weapons: handaxe, rapier, shortsword, and shortbow.
until CoT levels.

Yeah, I know, it was pointed out already. 

Still, that really breaks the immersion imo.  We all know the young Leonidas hunted that wolf with a spear.  But even assuming that Spear and Shield is taught much later (when the necessary muscle strength is there ;) ), that leaves a shortsword and...nothing.  Talk about Sparta hard!

Wouldn't be so bad, but it comes later.

ATM, at level 5, almost level 6 on WoG.  These are the things I am currently encountering as I level up.  UMD is now high enough to use Crafted Wands. Time to go Buggie hunting in Critwall and get in some power levelling!  Hopefully, enough to get that CoT level!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Level 7 now.

Took on some street gangs in the alley ways of Greyhawk City.  They kept Taunting me (lack of Concentration here is a serious flaw in this build!).  Dropped my AC to meh, and then were sneak attacking me (I guess they have more than enough levels of Rogue to do it).

Due to my very fast and quick reflexes (no, nope, no dexer here, dammit!), I ran away, tried hiding around corners...not very successful.

Downed many a curing potion, as the fight dragged on.  Couldn't land one KD due to low AB (another really meh part of this build).

Not very Sparta-like at all.  More like totally desperate, try anything to survive stuff. Nice XP tho.

Finally got some Crafted Wands (Impr. Invis, Flame Arrow, and Lesser Missile Storm).  Giddy with my newfound powah!

Gonna wreck some buggies in Critwall! 

All your XP belong to us! Aroo!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I know what you mean about Concentration - I like to take it when I can - but it is very environment-specific for non-casters. Not everywhere taunts (WoG does, and so does Aielund, to a lesser extent).

All woes could be solved by taking Fighter instead of CoT, I know, but I'm a bit addicted to decent saves (or at least less crappy ones, anyway).

Keep going, Web - and think of all that current frustration you can vent on baddies later on!

Cheers

Dammit!

Time to go to the Rift, and hunt some Stone Giants!  The bigger they are, the harder they fall...and even a God can bleed!

Aroo!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I feel your pain, Web. It's a long-standing beef of mine. Both shortsword and spear could historically be used as stabbing (piercing) and slashing weapons. Much as the greatsword was initially introduced to knock cavalry from their horses - thus bludgeoning and slashing. It's a bummer when you're trying to design a build that's as "true" to the character as possible, then having the game rules bite you on the arse.

Still, level 20!

AROO!

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: It’s a longshot, a real long longshot, but it is possible to find one of those weapons with an “extra damage type: slashing” property. But I wouldn’t bank on it.

posts.author: webshaman1

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content: Level 22.  No dirtnaps yet.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
After playing this build now for half of it's levels, it really seems like this build wants to be two different types of characters.

It starts out roguey, but never gets enough skills to really be roguey, then switches to beat'em up.  I am wondering if having a level of Rogue near level 20 might be a good idea (to top off some roguey skills).  22 does seem like a good spot (I mean, Tumble to 25, yadda yadda yadda).

I can't sneak up on anyone (sneak is too low, even with maxed out skills at Rogue 11) now, because most creatures at Epic levels spot me easily, me creeping along, they chuckling softly and elbowing each other as I try to sneak up on them, only for them to smack me hard to remind me that I am being like Drax in Avengers Infinity War - no, I am not invisible, yes, they can see me.  So right now I am depending on my Wand of Impr. Invis.

Same thing goes for opening locks and disarming traps.  Often now, ranges are a tick out of my standard range, and I have to rely on boosts to open locks and disarm traps (not to mention recover the traps, which is what I actually want to do). Meh.

I am REALLY missing Concentration on WoG!  I get taunted all the time now - well, there goes our AC, guys!  But beat'em up has prevented me from dirtnapping so far, so...yeah.  I am dreading higher levels.

ATM, I am trying to find out if the Short Spear is Finesseable.  If it is, it might be smarter to go the Dex route here (Shortsword is also Finesseable).  Better AC (and I am pretty sure Spartans didn't have any heavy armor, and at one period of time they wore none).  It would make sense if a Short Spear was Finesseable (it is almost the same as a Rapier, only a Rapier has a much better crit range).

Now, I know I still have 3 more levels of Rogue to go.  But getting to one to do a skill dump is showing areas in the build that are slumps, like valleys. 

Anyway, onwards!

Arroo!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, looking very kewl, oh shaman of webs!

WM coming up - and a fair dollop of it. Enjoy!

EDIT: Ninja'd! I understand what you say about Rogue levels, but remember, this is meant to be a RP PC, and I don't recall much in Greek myth or history about sneaky Spartans. Also, please refer to the first line of the OP, this is kind of two challenges in one. One, to build a Rogue/ CoT/ WM. Two, build a Spartan (not the small, recruitable dragon in Aielund). It was never going to be a walk in the park. A DEX version might work, though, and ED becomes an option then, with some juggling.

Oh, and I assume you know the looking kewl line refers to the screenshot.

Drats.

Oh, and just because it is an RP build, doesn't mean that it can't be optimized.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
webshaman1 wrote: ↑
Oct 16, 2020
 Oh, and just because it is an RP build, doesn't mean that it can't be optimized.
Fair point, Web. I've been engaged in a similar discussion with Max lately, so now I have the collected wisdom of two of the big boys bearing down on me. Much as I hate admitting it, it appears Max was right (*sighs* yes, again). And yourself, of course.

I have been looking at a more "hardcore" Spartan, dropping CoT for Fighter. It's currently at F14/ R7/ WM19. The saves are pretty diabolical, and I've swapped Shortsword for Scimitar, but it's got EWF and EWS in both weapons, along with Imp Crits and 2 WoCs, giving an AB of 48 with both. It also has access to Concentration. Obviously, the number of skill points suffers, but I'm working things through as I speak (well, you know what I mean). If it's worth a look, I'll drop it in here for your thoughts.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Okay, here's the different version I mention above. It's only a first (rough) draft, but it would seem to answer at least some of Web's concerns (though I daresay it will raise others). I lose Crippling Strike and have a pretty catastrophic Will save, but I gain in weapon capability, damage, and diversity. The skills take a hit, but can still incorporate Concentration alongside Discipline, Tumble, UMD, a detect skill, and a bundle of other useful stuff (still can't make him sneaky, even if I wanted to).

The ordering of feats is still malleable (such as whether to take spear or scimitar first), but see what you think...

Leonidas II - The More Focused One
Fighter 14/ Rogue 7/ WM 19
Human - Any (L1-40, PvM)

Stats
STR 17 (32)
DEX 14*
CON 14
WIS 8
INT 13*
CHA 8

(* if opting for heavy armour, drop DEX to 13 and bump INT to 14)

HPs: 452
Saves: Fort 22, Will 15, Reflex 24 (+4 v spells if opting for (cc) Spellcraft)
AC: 22 (naked), +3 (tower shield), +7 (heavy armour) [+5 if opting for just breastplate]
BAB: 29
AB: (only done melee) (max, WoC, both spear and scimitar) 48/ 43/ 38/ 33
SPs: 232. Max Discipline, Concentration (as far as Fighter allows), Tumble 40 (42), UMD 34 (33), Intimidate 4 (3). Plenty more to distribute between detect skills, Spellcraft (cc), trapping, locks, and stealth, according to taste.

Levelling

1 R1: Expertise/ Dodge
2 F1: WF: Spear
3 F2: WF: Scimitar/ Blind Fight
4 F3: STR+1 (18)
5 F4: WS: Spear
6 F5: Knockdown
7 F6: WS: Scimitar
8 R2: STR+1 (19)
9 F7: Mobility
10 F8: Imp Crit: Spear
11 F9
12 F10: STR+1 (20)/ Spring Attack/ Whirlwind Attack
13 R3
14 WM1: {WoC: Spear}
15 WM2: Imp Crit: Scimitar
16 WM3: STR+1 (21)
17 WM4
18 R4: Imp Knockdown
19 WM5
20 WM6: STR+1 (22)
21 WM7: EWF: Spear
22 WM8
23 R5
24 WM9: STR+1 (23)/ EWF: Scimitar
25 WM10
26 WM11
27 WM12: Great Strength I (24)
28 WM13: STR+1 (25)/ WoC: Scimitar
29 F11
30 F12: Great Strength II (26)/ EWS: Spear
31 F13
32 R6: STR+1 (27)
33 F14: Great Strength III (28)/ EWS: Scimitar
34 WM14
35 WM15
36 WM16: STR+1 (29)/ Great Strength IV (30)/ Armor Skin
37 R7
38 WM17
39 WM18: Great Strength V (31)
40 WM19: STR+1 (32)/ Epic Prowess

Any thoughts?

Cheers

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Why is Rogue in the build?  What I mean by this is, what role is it really serving?  Before it at least gained Crippling Strike (a nice combat bonus!) which really made sense in a Spartan (imo).

In this case...I am wondering, why Rogue?  No reason to have UD as Dex is...not an issue.  If for Tumble, perhaps a different Tumble class might fit the bill better.

If it is for UMD, well, that is not really RP at all if we are talking about a professional, focused Warrior.

I kind of like the inclusion of Fighter here.  It's an obvious choice that leads to WM (which is also an obvious choice).  Scimi is just...I know, I know.  It is frustrating.  Just seems like it is the better weapon all ways around.  I would still stay with the Shortsword (it is not as bad as it seems...well, it is because of AAs).  I really like the idea of WoC in both types of weapons.

I am thinking more Fighter, more WM.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
This is interesting!
The Kopis – The Nasty Spartan Weapon

As an alternative to the xiphos some Spartans selected the dreaded Kopis as their secondary weapon. This was a vicious hacking weapon in the form of a thick, curved iron sword. Warriors would use this weapon more as an axe then a sword, inflicting nasty wounds compared to the cleaner holes made by the spear and xiphos. This weapon was seen as the quintessential "bad guys" weapon in ancient Greece. Athenian art frequently depicted Spartan warriors with this weapon for that reason.
So perhaps a Scimi or a Kukri!  After all, most Spartan weapons were very short (well, not the speer, of course) - typically shorter than most Greek shortswords (and when a greek asked a Spartan why his sword was so short, the Spartan replied "it's long enough to reach your heart!")  The blade does have a lot in common with a Kukri as well, with that large curve in it.  This would be the reason for having a slashing and a piercing weapon (short spear).

Much better.  Also, Spartans did wear Armor (and although this is not the full plate armor of medieval knights) it was more than just a breastplate.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'll confess, Rogue is really there for skill points (though a little sneak attack doesn't hurt) to try to accommodate a panoply of the buggers for you. I actually started off with a Fighter 16/ Rogue 2/ WM 22, which allowed for a final STR of 34 because I could take both general feats used for EWF as bonus feats, freeing the pair up for Great Strength feats. If I didn't take any Rogue levels until epic levels, that would also give me +3 AB (1 GS, 1 pre-epic BAB, and 1 WM bonus feat), making 51.

But it's a bit of a bastard to level-up through the ranks, and you've already complained about Tumble dumps.

I also considered grabbing Epic Will as a general feat to help with the horrible Will save, which would mean lowering my final Strength back to 32 (starting with 16), but allowing for upping the starting INT to 14 and putting the WIS to 10 (meaning a Will save of 20, which is always a target for me), thus grabbing a further full skill while still having 50 AB.

Would that suit you better? I can't honestly say SD, Bard, Monk, HS, or Ass seem to make more sense than Rogue here. Maybe SD for HiPS, but the stealth skills would be crappy, and I still don't see Spartans as sneakers.

Glad you like the 2 WoCs. I thought scimitar was acceptable, as Spartan shortswords were curved and single-edged, as well as being shorter than longswords (no shit, Sherlock), so more slashing in nature anyway. But anyhoo...

Cheers

EDIT: Ninja'd again! (It's that bloody Nightshade, isn't it?). The only problem with kukri is the necessity to take Exotic Weapon Proficiency, thus having to bin something else.
